trans-unit.source: Manage DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Manage DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Managing DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS when hosting your domain on Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Managing DNS record sets and records on Azure DNS when hosting your domain on Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: All PowerShell commands for operations on record sets and records.
trans-unit.target: All PowerShell commands for operations on record sets and records.

trans-unit.source: How to manage DNS records
trans-unit.target: How to manage DNS records

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.SELECTOR]
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.SELECTOR]

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Azure Powershell
trans-unit.target: Azure Powershell

trans-unit.source: This guide will show how to manage record sets and records for your DNS zone.
trans-unit.target: This guide will show how to manage record sets and records for your DNS zone.

trans-unit.source: It is important to understand the distinction between DNS record sets and individual DNS records.
trans-unit.target: It is important to understand the distinction between DNS record sets and individual DNS records.

trans-unit.source: A record set is the collection of records in a zone with the same name and the same type.
trans-unit.target: A record set is the collection of records in a zone with the same name and the same type.

trans-unit.source: For more details, see [Understanding record sets and records](../dns-getstarted-create-recordset#Understanding-record-sets-and-records).
trans-unit.target: For more details, see [Understanding record sets and records](../dns-getstarted-create-recordset#Understanding-record-sets-and-records).

trans-unit.source: Create a record set
trans-unit.target: Create a record set

trans-unit.source: Record sets are created using the New-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Record sets are created using the New-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You need to specify the record set name, the zone, the Time-to-Live (TTL) and the record type.
trans-unit.target: You need to specify the record set name, the zone, the Time-to-Live (TTL) and the record type.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The record set name must be a relative name, excluding the zone name.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The record set name must be a relative name, excluding the zone name.

trans-unit.source: For example, the record set name ‘www’ in zone ‘contoso.com’ will create a record set with the fully-qualified name ‘www.contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: For example, the record set name ‘www’ in zone ‘contoso.com’ will create a record set with the fully-qualified name ‘www.contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: For a record set at the zone apex, use "@" as the record set name, including quotation marks.
trans-unit.target: For a record set at the zone apex, use "@" as the record set name, including quotation marks.

trans-unit.source: The fully-qualified name of the record set is then equal to the zone name, in this case "contoso.com".
trans-unit.target: The fully-qualified name of the record set is then equal to the zone name, in this case "contoso.com".

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS supports the following record types: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, SOA, SRV, TXT.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS supports the following record types: A, AAAA, CNAME, MX, NS, SOA, SRV, TXT.

trans-unit.source: Record sets of type SOA are created automatically with each zone, they cannot be created separately.
trans-unit.target: Record sets of type SOA are created automatically with each zone, they cannot be created separately.

trans-unit.source: If a record set already exists, the command will fail unless the -Overwrite switch is used.
trans-unit.target: If a record set already exists, the command will fail unless the -Overwrite switch is used.

trans-unit.source: The ‘-Overwrite’ option will trigger a confirmation prompt, which can be suppressed using the -Force switch.
trans-unit.target: The ‘-Overwrite’ option will trigger a confirmation prompt, which can be suppressed using the -Force switch.

trans-unit.source: In the above example, the zone is specified using a zone object, as returned by Get-AzureDnsZone or New-AzureDnsZone.
trans-unit.target: In the above example, the zone is specified using a zone object, as returned by Get-AzureDnsZone or New-AzureDnsZone.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can also specify the zone by zone name and resource group name:
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can also specify the zone by zone name and resource group name:

trans-unit.source: New-AzureDnsRecordSet returns a local object representing the record set created in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: New-AzureDnsRecordSet returns a local object representing the record set created in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] CNAME record sets cannot co-exist with other record sets with the same name.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] CNAME record sets cannot co-exist with other record sets with the same name.

trans-unit.source: For example, you cannot create a CNAME with the relative name ‘www’ and an A record with the relative name ‘www’ at the same time.
trans-unit.target: For example, you cannot create a CNAME with the relative name ‘www’ and an A record with the relative name ‘www’ at the same time.

trans-unit.source: Since the zone apex (name = ‘@’) always contains the NS and SOA record sets created when the zone is created, this means you cannot create a CNAME record set at the zone apex.
trans-unit.target: Since the zone apex (name = ‘@’) always contains the NS and SOA record sets created when the zone is created, this means you cannot create a CNAME record set at the zone apex.

trans-unit.source: These constraints arise from the DNS standards, they are not limitations of Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: These constraints arise from the DNS standards, they are not limitations of Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: Wildcard records
trans-unit.target: Wildcard records

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS supports [wildcard records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildcard_DNS_record).
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS supports [wildcard records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildcard_DNS_record).

trans-unit.source: These are returned for any query with a matching name (unless there is a closer match from a non-wildcard record set).
trans-unit.target: These are returned for any query with a matching name (unless there is a closer match from a non-wildcard record set).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To create a wildcard record set, use the record set name "\*", or a name whose first label is "\*", e.g. "\*.foo".
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To create a wildcard record set, use the record set name "\*", or a name whose first label is "\*", e.g. "\*.foo".

trans-unit.source: Wildcard record sets are supported for all record types except NS and SOA.
trans-unit.target: Wildcard record sets are supported for all record types except NS and SOA.

trans-unit.source: Get a record set
trans-unit.target: Get a record set

trans-unit.source: To retrieve an existing record set, use ‘Get-AzureDnsRecordSet’, specifying the record set relative name, the record type, and the zone:
trans-unit.target: To retrieve an existing record set, use ‘Get-AzureDnsRecordSet’, specifying the record set relative name, the record type, and the zone:

trans-unit.source: As with New-AzureDnsRecordSet, the record name must be a relative name, i.e. excluding the zone name.
trans-unit.target: As with New-AzureDnsRecordSet, the record name must be a relative name, i.e. excluding the zone name.

trans-unit.source: The zone can be specified using either a zone object (as above) or by zone name and resource group name:
trans-unit.target: The zone can be specified using either a zone object (as above) or by zone name and resource group name:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzureDnsRecordSet returns a local object representing the record set created in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Get-AzureDnsRecordSet returns a local object representing the record set created in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: List record sets
trans-unit.target: List record sets

trans-unit.source: By omitting the –Name and/or –RecordType parameters, Get-AzureDnsRecordSet can also be used to list record sets:
trans-unit.target: By omitting the –Name and/or –RecordType parameters, Get-AzureDnsRecordSet can also be used to list record sets:

trans-unit.source: Option 1
trans-unit.target: Option 1

trans-unit.source: List all record sets.
trans-unit.target: List all record sets.

trans-unit.source: This will return all record sets, regardless of name or record type:
trans-unit.target: This will return all record sets, regardless of name or record type:

trans-unit.source: Option 2
trans-unit.target: Option 2

trans-unit.source: List record sets of a given record type.
trans-unit.target: List record sets of a given record type.

trans-unit.source: This will return all record sets matching the given record type (in this case, A records):
trans-unit.target: This will return all record sets matching the given record type (in this case, A records):

trans-unit.source: In both cases above, the zone can be specified using either a zone object (as shown) or by specifying the –ZoneName and –ResourceGroupName parameters.
trans-unit.target: In both cases above, the zone can be specified using either a zone object (as shown) or by specifying the –ZoneName and –ResourceGroupName parameters.

trans-unit.source: Add a record to a record set
trans-unit.target: Add a record to a record set

trans-unit.source: Records are added to record sets using the Add-AzureDnsRecordConfig cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Records are added to record sets using the Add-AzureDnsRecordConfig cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This is an off-line operation—only the local object representing the record set is changed.
trans-unit.target: This is an off-line operation—only the local object representing the record set is changed.

trans-unit.source: The parameters for adding records to a record set vary depending on the type of the record set.
trans-unit.target: The parameters for adding records to a record set vary depending on the type of the record set.

trans-unit.source: For example, when using a record set of type 'A' you will only be able to specify records with the parameter ‘IPv4Address’.
trans-unit.target: For example, when using a record set of type 'A' you will only be able to specify records with the parameter ‘IPv4Address’.

trans-unit.source: Additional records can be added to each record set by additional calls to Add-AzureDnsRecordConfig.
trans-unit.target: Additional records can be added to each record set by additional calls to Add-AzureDnsRecordConfig.

trans-unit.source: You can add up to 100 records to any record set.
trans-unit.target: You can add up to 100 records to any record set.

trans-unit.source: However, record sets of type CNAME can contain at most 1 record, and a record set cannot contain two identical records.
trans-unit.target: However, record sets of type CNAME can contain at most 1 record, and a record set cannot contain two identical records.

trans-unit.source: Empty record sets (with zero records) can be created, but do not appear at the Azure DNS name servers.
trans-unit.target: Empty record sets (with zero records) can be created, but do not appear at the Azure DNS name servers.

trans-unit.source: Once the record set contains the desired collection of records, it needs to be committed using the Set-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet, which replaces the existing record set in Azure DNS with the record set provided.
trans-unit.target: Once the record set contains the desired collection of records, it needs to be committed using the Set-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet, which replaces the existing record set in Azure DNS with the record set provided.

trans-unit.source: The following examples show how to create a record set of each record type containing a single record.
trans-unit.target: The following examples show how to create a record set of each record type containing a single record.

trans-unit.source: Create A record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create A record set with single record

trans-unit.source: The sequence of operations to create a record can also be ‘piped’, passing the record set object using the pipe rather than as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: The sequence of operations to create a record can also be ‘piped’, passing the record set object using the pipe rather than as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Create AAAA record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create AAAA record set with single record

trans-unit.source: Create CNAME record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create CNAME record set with single record

trans-unit.source: Create MX record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create MX record set with single record

trans-unit.source: In this example, we use the record set name "@" to create the MX record at the zone apex (e.g. "contoso.com").
trans-unit.target: In this example, we use the record set name "@" to create the MX record at the zone apex (e.g. "contoso.com").

trans-unit.source: This is common for MX records.
trans-unit.target: This is common for MX records.

trans-unit.source: Create NS record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create NS record set with single record

trans-unit.source: Create SRV record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create SRV record set with single record

trans-unit.source: If creating an SRV record in root of zone, just specify _service and _protocol in the record name—there is no need to also include ‘.@’ in the record name
trans-unit.target: If creating an SRV record in root of zone, just specify _service and _protocol in the record name—there is no need to also include ‘.@’ in the record name

trans-unit.source: Create TXT record set with single record
trans-unit.target: Create TXT record set with single record

trans-unit.source: Modifying existing record sets
trans-unit.target: Modifying existing record sets

trans-unit.source: Modifying existing record sets follows a similar pattern to creating records.
trans-unit.target: Modifying existing record sets follows a similar pattern to creating records.

trans-unit.source: The sequence of operations is as follows:
trans-unit.target: The sequence of operations is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve the existing record set using Get-AzureDnsRecordSet.
trans-unit.target: Retrieve the existing record set using Get-AzureDnsRecordSet.

trans-unit.source: Modify the record set, by either adding records, removing records, changing the record parameters or changing the record set TTL.
trans-unit.target: Modify the record set, by either adding records, removing records, changing the record parameters or changing the record set TTL.

trans-unit.source: These changes are off-line—only the local object representing the record set is changed.
trans-unit.target: These changes are off-line—only the local object representing the record set is changed.

trans-unit.source: Commit your changes using the Set-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Commit your changes using the Set-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This replaces the existing record set in Azure DNS with the record set provided.
trans-unit.target: This replaces the existing record set in Azure DNS with the record set provided.

trans-unit.source: This is shown by the following examples:
trans-unit.target: This is shown by the following examples:

trans-unit.source: Update a record in an existing record set
trans-unit.target: Update a record in an existing record set

trans-unit.source: For this example we will change the IP address of an existing A record:
trans-unit.target: For this example we will change the IP address of an existing A record:

trans-unit.source: The Set-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet uses ‘etag’ checks to ensure concurrent changes are not overwritten.
trans-unit.target: The Set-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet uses ‘etag’ checks to ensure concurrent changes are not overwritten.

trans-unit.source: Use the ‘-Overwrite’ flag to suppress these checks.
trans-unit.target: Use the ‘-Overwrite’ flag to suppress these checks.

trans-unit.source: See Etags and Tags for more information.
trans-unit.target: See Etags and Tags for more information.

trans-unit.source: Modify SOA record
trans-unit.target: Modify SOA record

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot add or remove records from the automatically-created SOA record set at the zone apex (name = ‘@’), but you can modify the parameters within the SOA record and the record set TTL.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot add or remove records from the automatically-created SOA record set at the zone apex (name = ‘@’), but you can modify the parameters within the SOA record and the record set TTL.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to change the ‘Email’ property of the SOA record:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to change the ‘Email’ property of the SOA record:

trans-unit.source: Modify NS records at zone apex
trans-unit.target: Modify NS records at zone apex

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot add to, remove or modify the records in the automatically-created NS record set at the zone apex (name = ‘@’).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot add to, remove or modify the records in the automatically-created NS record set at the zone apex (name = ‘@’).

trans-unit.source: The only change permitted is to modify the record set TTL.
trans-unit.target: The only change permitted is to modify the record set TTL.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to change the TTL property of the NS record set:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to change the TTL property of the NS record set:

trans-unit.source: Add records to an existing record set
trans-unit.target: Add records to an existing record set

trans-unit.source: In this example we add two additional MX records to the existing record set:
trans-unit.target: In this example we add two additional MX records to the existing record set:

trans-unit.source: Remove a record from an existing record set
trans-unit.target: Remove a record from an existing record set

trans-unit.source: Records can be removed from a record set using Remove-AzureDnsRecordConfig.
trans-unit.target: Records can be removed from a record set using Remove-AzureDnsRecordConfig.

trans-unit.source: Note that the record being removed must be an exact match with an existing record, across all parameters.
trans-unit.target: Note that the record being removed must be an exact match with an existing record, across all parameters.

trans-unit.source: Changes must be committed using Set-AzureDnsRecordSet.
trans-unit.target: Changes must be committed using Set-AzureDnsRecordSet.

trans-unit.source: Removing the last record from a record set does not delete the record set.
trans-unit.target: Removing the last record from a record set does not delete the record set.

trans-unit.source: See [Delete a record set](#delete-a-record-set) below for more.
trans-unit.target: See [Delete a record set](#delete-a-record-set) below for more.

trans-unit.source: The sequence of operations to remove a record from a record set can also be ‘piped’, passing the record set object using the pipe rather than as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: The sequence of operations to remove a record from a record set can also be ‘piped’, passing the record set object using the pipe rather than as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Remove AAAA record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove AAAA record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Remove CNAME record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove CNAME record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Since a CNAME record set can contain at most one record, removing that record will leave an empty record set.
trans-unit.target: Since a CNAME record set can contain at most one record, removing that record will leave an empty record set.

trans-unit.source: Remove MX record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove MX record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Remove NS record from record set
trans-unit.target: Remove NS record from record set

trans-unit.source: Remove SRV record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove SRV record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Remove TXT record from a record set
trans-unit.target: Remove TXT record from a record set

trans-unit.source: Delete a record set
trans-unit.target: Delete a record set

trans-unit.source: Record sets can be deleted using the Remove-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Record sets can be deleted using the Remove-AzureDnsRecordSet cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot delete the SOA and NS record sets at the zone apex (name = ‘@’) that are created automatically when the zone is created.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You cannot delete the SOA and NS record sets at the zone apex (name = ‘@’) that are created automatically when the zone is created.

trans-unit.source: They will be deleted automatically when deleting the zone.
trans-unit.target: They will be deleted automatically when deleting the zone.

trans-unit.source: Use one of the following three ways to remove a record set:
trans-unit.target: Use one of the following three ways to remove a record set:

trans-unit.source: Option 1
trans-unit.target: Option 1

trans-unit.source: Specify the all parameters by name:
trans-unit.target: Specify the all parameters by name:

trans-unit.source: The optional ‘-Force’ switch can be used to suppress the confirmation prompt.
trans-unit.target: The optional ‘-Force’ switch can be used to suppress the confirmation prompt.

trans-unit.source: Option 2
trans-unit.target: Option 2

trans-unit.source: Specify the record set by name and type, specify the zone by object:
trans-unit.target: Specify the record set by name and type, specify the zone by object:

trans-unit.source: Option 3
trans-unit.target: Option 3

trans-unit.source: Specify the record set by object:
trans-unit.target: Specify the record set by object:

trans-unit.source: Specifying the record set using an object enables ‘etag’ checks to ensure concurrent changes are not deleted.
trans-unit.target: Specifying the record set using an object enables ‘etag’ checks to ensure concurrent changes are not deleted.

trans-unit.source: The optional ‘-Overwrite’ flag suppresses these checks.
trans-unit.target: The optional ‘-Overwrite’ flag suppresses these checks.

trans-unit.source: See [Etags and tags](../dns-getstarted-create-dnszone#Etags-and-tags) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [Etags and tags](../dns-getstarted-create-dnszone#Etags-and-tags) for more information.

trans-unit.source: The record set object can also be piped instead of being passed as a parameter:
trans-unit.target: The record set object can also be piped instead of being passed as a parameter:
